entry.content:
With the results of the United States Presidential Election in November 2024, there was a tectonic shift in the thinking of individuals that do want to speak truth to power, but also do not want to be unwise in the act. My blog is primarily about speaking the truth about XR for learning around and despite some very powerful companies and a few personal enemies.

I'm old enough that the lessons of World War II are not lost on me.Â  The time period between November 2024 and this blog going live in June/July 2025 has caused many to harken of 1920s Germany. Indeed, several new phrases have been circulating in my head.

Do not obey in advance is one.

But another idea is to not give up my data, even if I'm utilizing my free speech rights as a US citizen. The idea that one would not be caught up in being arrested or worst if one is doing nothing wrong...is behind us. The monster eats and it eats anyone it can get.

â€œ...Whenever they catch you, they will kill you. But first they must catch you, digger, listener, runner, prince with the swift warning. Be cunning and full of tricks...â€
â€• Richard Adams, Watership Down


That idea lead me to the lovely Opt Out Project blog.

Even though I had no direct reason for jumping ship from blogger/blogspot...how MUCH big tech is scraping personal accounts for data now just friggin scares me.Â  I left Twitter/X because of their new policy so take anything anyone posts as food for their AI.Â  I create and share my creations. I was like...uh, no, you are not free to take my stuff.Â  So I left, deleting everything in my wake.



Leaving blogger/blogspot is another in the steps I'm taking to get away from big tech.

So that means that you have arrived here. It took me 4 months to get this blog up and running.Â  To the best of my ability, here is what it does.

1. I don't care about number counting reads. Read counts stoke vanity. I've also never activated replies to my posts. If you want to respond, do so on your own blog, thankyouverymuch. ğŸ§ I try very hard to not count nor look at the numbers of anything I create.Â  It's not. about. the. numbers. ğŸš«ğŸ”¢

2. This blog is hosted on Github Pages, which is at this time a Microsoft product. I encourage you to visit using a VPN because they are probably tracking IPs, but I do not receive the information. I do not have ANY analytics that I have activated on this blog.Â Â 

3. I'm using Publii and since I only post blog posts and nothing else (no stores, no forms, no mailing lists...I guess the kids call this static HTML now) I do not plan on adding ANY plugins. I'm using a basic theme available from Publii.Â  I'll let you know here and in the cookie banner if that changes in the future.

4. I'm going to attempt to set up the cookie banner to be meaningless for collecting anything and to strongly encourage you to Reject cookies. Let's hope I figure that out.

Oh and one more thing, I do not monetize anything here. Nothing.Â  By willingly turning my back on all forms of monetization, I'm never working for someone else that will show up as bias in my writing.

As Opt Out Project writes: No trackers. No fingerprints. No data collection.

Let us all live long and prosper.

entry.title: Death Comes Closely Now

entry.content:
Â 

Â 

Chances are that, with the COVID-19 pandemic, someone you know, a family member or a friend, will die within this horror. There are already stories of children learning that their parents have died, states away and alone. Spouses are losing their life partner without so much as one last â€œI Love Youâ€ before the insertion of a ventilator. Funerals are currently outlawed. We may run out of coffins. Indeed, death comes closely now.

When it comes to death,Â people donâ€™t know what to sayÂ or do. Additionally, because we are socially isolated now, some of the structures surrounding death will be denied to us. Funeral directors normally help us navigate the first few days of grief; now plans have to be made for â€˜when we can get back togetherâ€™. What do we do when the grief experience is literally and figurativelyâ€¦remote?

Indeed, it can be hard to find our way through this verse when our very concepts of death and time become tangled and swamped:

Ecclesiastes 3:1,2

1 There is a time for everything,
and a season for every activity under the heavens:

2 a time to be born and a time to die,

I want to offer some words of advice about how to navigate this sea of grief that we are all about to wade unwillingly into. Admittedly, these words work best at the societal level, but they will work at the personal level if you will take them to heart.

Elana Premack Sandler, L.C.S.W., M.P.H, writes about what she calls the Ring Theory with the main idea ofÂ Comfort In, Dump Out. Please do read her article at Psychology TodayÂ here. It contains some great examples of what to say (or not) and do when death arrives.

Â 

I would modify her words to â€œEmote Out, Care In.â€

The basic idea here is that whenever tragedy or death occurs, the person closest emotionally to the event (Iâ€™ll call them â€˜the bereavedâ€™) gets TO HAVE EVERY EMOTION THEY WANT. Yes, this is important. That person can be sad, happy, angry, in denial, relieved, or fearful. That person gets to emote out (dump out) any emotion they want for as long as they want.

The second part isÂ care in. This means that in successive societal circles around the bereaved, each circle does what one can to pour careÂ inÂ towards the bereaved. Each circle has a zone of control where they can execute their powers.

For example, immediately around the bereaved is likely family (spouse, children, siblings). Their care inÂ duties will often be the most personal and direct but also the most hidden and quiet. They may help pick out clothing for the body. They can stay with the bereaved until a few days have passed, making sure that the bereaved can do things like eat, drink, and sleep.

The next outer circle might contain the childrenâ€™s bosses at their place of employment, who care in by granting as much bereavement leave as possible. Churches often are in this circle too and they can arrange meal delivery or communicate prayer requests. Circles further out are societal structures of updating paperwork or processing a death certificate.

What should NOT happen is mixing the emoting out and caring in.

SoÂ DO NOT EMOTE IN.

Examples of emoting in include cruel statements like: â€œYou should be glad he is with our Lordâ€ or â€œIt is blessing that you donâ€™t have to worry about his constant care anymore.â€ That is pouring an emotion in. No. Never do that. You have no right.Â NO EMOTION INÂ towards the center. No level can emote in to a level that is closer to the center.

Also, you canâ€™t expect the bereaved to send care out. This is not the time to ask them to make your favorite cake. Itâ€™s just not right.

Now, each person gets to play a role in grieving. Just because a spouse is the center of her circle over the death of her husband doesnâ€™t mean that each child will also be the center of their own circles over the death of their father. So the circles do overlap. The point is to recognize who is closer the rawness of death and cede the emotional center to themÂ at that moment.

I offer this advice as someone for whom death has been a companion. Iâ€™ve lost many treasured family members over the past 15 years and learned that grief is not like a wave that you stand up from, recover, brush yourself off, and look ahead. You donâ€™t get over it. You get changed by it. Grief is a like yeast to bread; it works it's way into every part of the loaf. Grief changes you and makes you see perspective.

Grief makes you love deeper, laugh more, and cry harder.

From my experience, I send you hope. Life changes. Sweetness arrives again in birdsong or a childâ€™s laughter. Pain subsides like the tide pulling away. You will begin to fear death less when you realize that we are all together in this journey.

Peace to you.

Psalms 23:4
Even though I walk
through the darkest valley,
I will fear no evil,
for you are with me;
